(Bloomberg) -- Apple is generally seeing robust demand for its iPhone 12 models, analysts wrote, with Wedbush pointing to a Nikkei Asia report on production. Shares up 1.7% premarket.
According to the report, Apple is planning to produce up to 96 million iPhones in the first half of 2021, a 30% year-over-year increase
The 96 million figure is “well ahead of Street expectations,” wrote Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives, who called the Nikkei report “another bullish sign of iPhone 12 demand”
While Wall Street is expecting 215 million iPhone units to be sold in FY21, Apple “has potential to sell north of 240 million units,” with China demand “a linchpin” to this success
Outperform, PT remains a Street-high $160
Separately, KeyBanc Capital Markets wrote that its data suggest mixed sales trends for different iPhone models
“Demand for the iPhone 12 Pro and Max models were the most robust, while 12 sales were in line, while demand for the Mini has been clearly underwhelming,” analyst John Vinh wrote
User interest for the 12 Mini “appears relatively weak, as feedback indicates consumers prefer the larger form factors”
KeyBanc wrote that this data were “largely neutral” to the Apple supply chain, although “moderately negative” for Synaptics
In a note published Dec. 14, Evercore ISI wrote that November smartphone data “points to continued growth in iPhone shipments”
Outperform, PT $135
